question: Which of the following features is a characteristic feature of upper motor neuron disease?
Lacrimation, rhinorrhea, vomiting, and nausea are symptoms indicating withdrawal of which of the following substances?
Which of the following neurological diseases has the highest mortality rate?

An 18-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of trouble walking properly. She cannot maintain her balance and stumbles often. Upon asking her to pace the room, it is observed her gait is uneven. Which of the following is a likely etiology of her condition?

A 71-year-old male presents to the emergency room with complaints of slurring speech and trouble understanding those around him. He is unable to comprehend simple commands given by the doctor and cannot vocalize his problems. What parts of the brain are damaged in this man?

answers.option: Primary motor cortex and Broadman area 8

question: A 13-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of trouble walking. She is asked to stand still but begins to sway. A Romberg's test is conducted and the patient is asked to close her eyes while standing and the swaying worsens. Which of the following is a likely cause of her walking problems?

A 40-year-old male presents with a disconjugate gaze such that when looking to the left, his left eye moves while his right eye stays fixed. A lesion in which of the following sites is most likely responsible for this presentation?

A 31-year-old female presents to the emergency room with a headache, fever, and swelling around the eyes. She has had a history of sinusitis for the past 4 months. Examination revealed decreased visual acuity, diminished pupillary reflexes, ptosis, periorbital edema, and painful eye movement. Fundoscopic examination shows papilledema. Vitals include a temperature of 102°F, a heart rate of 110 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 130/87 mmHg. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?

A 45-year-old male patient presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of progressive walking difficulty for the past year. Nine months ago he noticed weakness in his grip with thinning of his hand muscles first on the right and then on the left side. There are no sensory complaints or sphincter disturbance. On examination, there is muscle wasting with a power of 3/5 proximally and distally in both lower limbs with brisk reflexes. Asymmetric wasting is present in both his hands with intact reflexes. An oral cavity examination shows fine rippling movement in the tongue. What is the most likely diagnosis of this man's condition?

A 28-year-old man falls and rolls along the pavement for 100 m. He has multiple contusions and abrasions involving the skin of his torso and extremities, but none on his head. He is unconscious. There is no decerebrate posturing. A CT scan of the head shows no intracranial hemorrhage or edema and no skull fractures. He remains in a persistent vegetative state. Which of the following pathological findings is most likely to be present?

A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency room with sudden urinary retention and lower limb weakness. The neurosurgeon is called, urgent surgery is recommended after relevant imaging studies. To establish a diagnosis of cauda equina syndrome, besides the aforementioned symptoms, what other clinical feature must be present?

A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency room after head trauma with complaints of headache and bleeding from the right ear. CT scan shows a right temporal bone fracture. He is discharged after a period of observation. One week later he came with difficulty in closing the right eye, which of the following nerve is likely to be involved in this case?

A 60-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of neck pain and difficulty in carrying out daily activities. He has a previous history of falls. Neurological examination findings reveal weakness and sensory disturbance more on upper limbs than on lower limbs. What kind of spinal cord injury is most likely?
Which of the following statements is true regarding post-dural puncture headache?

answers.option: It is relieved within 12 hours by an epidural blood patch
It is not lessened by the use of a Whitacre needle as compared to a Quincke needle
It is most frequent with large-bore needles
It is aggravated by the supine position

question: Which of the following is not an indication for a X-ray?

A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of a chronic, dull headache, that feels like a tight band around his head. His headache is associated with neck stiffness but there is no association with nausea, vomiting, or photophobia. He has had this complaint for one year now. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is the most appropriate first step in the immediate management of a patient presenting to the emergency room with status epilepticus?

answers.option: Draw blood to send for complete blood count

question: A couple has brought their 6-year-old child to the outpatient department with the complaint that he has been remaining inattentive in class and seems to go blank and stare in space. There is no other significant past medical history. What is the going to be the most likely finding on electroencephalography (EEG)?
Which of the following conditions is a neurodegenerative disease?
Which of the following is the most likely to be the earliest finding in Parkinson disease?
Which of the following is true regarding acute viral encephalitis?

answers.option: Herpes RNA is detected by polymerase chain reaction (PCR)
Acyclovir 10 mg/kg 3 times daily for 2-3 weeks is given

question: Which of the following best describes pleocytosis in the cerebrospinal fluid?
Damage to which area of the brain can cause alexia and agraphia?
What type of speech is observed in patients with mania?
Which of the following is the most common type of hallucination in schizophrenia?
Which of the following is true regarding Guillain-Barré syndrome?

answers.option: Miller Fisher syndrome is a common variant

question: Sensorineural deafness is an integral part of which disease?

A 26-year-old female comes to the outpatient department with complaints of bilateral lower limb weakness and urinary incontinence for 3 days. She has a history of painful vision loss in the left eye a year ago which resolved on its own within few days. On examination, she has spastic paraparesis with sensory loss from the toes up to the level of the umbilicus. On funduscopic examination, there is optic atrophy on the left side. An MRI is ordered and T2 imaging shows areas of hyperintensities around the lateral ventricles and a post-contrast T1 sequence reveals a large hyperintense lesion in the spinal cord at the T8 level. The rest of the systemic examination was unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A lesion at the level of the optic chiasma leads to which of the following?
Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding myasthenia gravis?

answers.option: IgG antibodies against acetylcholine receptors are the main cause
D-penicillamine may relieve transient myasthenia gravis

question: A 37-year-old male presents with double vision. Initial evaluation concludes he has lateral rectus palsy. Which cranial nerve is most likely lesioned in this young man?

A 62-year-old man is brought to the neurology clinic by his son with complaints of walking slower every day and tremors of hands at rest for 1 year. In the last 6 months, he has also become forgetful of recent events and asks simple questions repeatedly. Recently, he started claiming that he could see an elephant and a tiger in his room. These problems have become progressively worse gradually. He has had a couple of falls in this period but luckily did not acquire any major injury. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

An unvaccinated, 18-month-old child is brought to the clinic with left lower limb weakness. His parents say that he had fever and diarrhea two days ago, which was managed with oral rehydration salts (ORS). Which of the following investigations is the most appropriate?
Which of the following is a major risk factor for most forms of dementia?

A 50-year-old man presents to the outpatient department (OPD) with the complaint of a severe headache on the side of his head for the past 6 months. He also complains of vision loss in his left eye, blackouts, low-grade fever, and weight loss. What is the most likely diagnosis?
What is the standard intravenous dose of recombinant plasminogen tissue activator in ischemic stroke patients?

A 45-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with an altered level of consciousness, and fever. His brother reports he has had a fever and neck stiffness for 2 days along with a rash on his arms and legs. What is the most probable diagnosis?

A 78-year-old male comes to the neurology outpatient clinic with complaints of diminished facial expression, stooping posture, slowing of voluntary movement, muscle rigidity, and a “pill-rolling” tremor. He complains of taking short quick-paced steps when walking. An acute parkinsonian syndrome and destruction of neurons in the substantia nigra follows exposure to which of the following toxins?

A 40-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of high-grade fever and a headache for the last 20 days. He describes the headache as gradual in onset and moderate in intensity. In the last 10 days, he suffered three episodes of generalized seizures followed by weakness on the right side of the body. He was recently treated for a middle ear infection last month. He has a history of diabetes mellitus, controlled with metformin twice daily. On examination, his GCS is 15/15, right-sided power 2/5 in the upper and lower right limb, and speech is slurred. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 50-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency department with an altered mental state and two episodes of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. He also complains of low-grade fever with headaches for the past month. On examination, GCS is 13/15, with bilateral 6th nerve palsy. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows a leukocyte count of 12/mm3 (N- 0-10/mm3) with predominant lymphocytes, protein 110 mg/dl (N <40 mg/dl), and glucose 40 mg/dl (N- 40-70 mg/dl). Gram and India ink staining were negative. MRI of the brain shows leptomeningeal enhancement in the base of the brain sections. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 6-year-old male child weighing 20 kgs is brought to emergency with a history of weakness in both lower extremities, which has now progressively involved the trunk and upper limbs over a period of ten days. On examination, the sensations are intact, the tone is reduced, and reflexes are not elicited in lower limbs and +1 in upper limbs. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 15-year-old boy presents with complaints of recurrent loss of consciousness followed by confusion. He had three similar episodes within the last 6 months. All these episodes are associated with the inability to recall the events that occurred during the episode. Trauma to the tongue and incontinence is observed by his family after each episode. Which of the following is the best procedure to reach an accurate diagnosis?

A 60-year-old male with uncontrolled hypertension, active smoker, alcohol abuse presents to the emergency room. On examination, he is drowsy, able to follow commands, has right mild facial paresis, right upper and lower extremity pronator drift, and has moderate spatial hemineglect. If there is a suspicion of a middle cerebral artery lesion in a stroke patient which of the following is present?

A 45-year-old male comes to an emergency room, with complaints of progressive weakness associated with decreased muscle mass and pain. On examination, there is muscle wasting and hyporeflexia. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis is consistent with aseptic meningitis. At what point can postpolio syndrome develop in a patient?

A 10-year-old boy presents to the neurology clinic with complaints of fever, headache, confusion, left eye drooping, and right-sided weakness for 4 days. He had a mild upper respiratory tract infection 2 weeks ago. On examination, he has left eye ptosis with restricted medial gaze, 3/5 power on the right upper and lower extremity with brisk reflexes, and an upgoing plantar. Signs of meningeal irritation were absent. An MRI of the brain shows multiple large confluent areas of hyperintensities in the bilateral subcortical region, midbrain, and cerebellum with patchy enhancement. His cerebrospinal fluid analysis revealed lymphocytic pleocytosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 50-year-old smoker presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of difficulty in rising above from the ground and holding heavy objects in her hands for 3-4 weeks. She has lost significant weight in the past few months. Upon examination, she had a low-grade fever, but the rest of the physical examination was normal. She had decreased power in hip and shoulder girdle muscles with normal reflexes and sensations. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein levels are raised. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 6-year-old boy presents to the clinic with his mother who complains that he is inattentive in class and seems to go blank and stare into space at times. The neurological examination is unremarkable. What would be the most likely finding on EEG?

A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room after several episodes of epigastric discomfort followed by loss of sensorium. According to the attendants, he appears to be conscious but is non-responsive to his surroundings. During these 2-3 minute episodes he continues to make chewing movements and look around aimlessly. He reports a mild headache after the episode. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 16-year-old girl presents to the emergency room with complaints of severe right-sided headache for the last 6 hours associated with vomiting and increased sensitivity to light and sounds. Vital signs were stable. What would be the best to differentiate between the sinister and benign causes of headaches?

A 28-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with a 9-year history of recurrent episodic headaches, lasting 30 minutes, at a frequency of 2-4 times a day. He claims that daily headache attacks lasted 3-4 weeks each year at the onset of winters but this year the attacks appeared at beginning of summer. The pain is excruciating and focused around his right eye. The right eye reddens, eyelid droops with ipsilateral clear nasal discharge. Physical examination, lumbar puncture, brain MRI (including pituitary views), and pituitary function blood tests are normal. What is the cause of this headache?

A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with abnormal movements of high frequency 10-12 Hertz involving his head and both the arms, bothering him mostly while taking meals and drinking water. His grandfather also had the same problem. What are these abnormal movements classified as?
Examination of a patient indicates that he has a medially directed strabismus (squint). This could be due to damage of what structure?

A 45-year-old female presents to the outpatient clinic with a history of progressive difficulty in walking for 6 months along with numbness in hands and feet. On examination, she has a bilateral high stepping gait with a positive Romberg sign. There was wasting and weakness of distal muscles of both upper and lower limbs with reduced reflexes. What will be the first investigation of choice to diagnose the disease?

A 22-year-old male presents to the emergency room with recurring seizures for 3 hours. He has been running a fever for 2 days while exhibiting irritable behavior. Currently, he is very agitated and needs to be physically restrained. His body temperature is 104°F. Signs of meningeal irritation are absent. Plain CT scan brain shows abnormal hypo-dense signals in both temporal lobes. What is an important consideration in the management of this patient?

answers.option: MRI brain is required as next step to confirm the diagnosis
Early control of seizures is mandatory for good outcome
Lumbar puncture is contraindicated because of abnormal findings in CT brain
Intravenous ceftriaxone is the drug of choice
Regular use of antipyretics may lead to early recovery

question: Which of the following is the most common sign of anterior territory circulation stroke?

An 81-year-old female comes to the neurology outpatient department with complaints of diminished facial expression (often termed masked facies), stooped posture, slowing of voluntary movement, taking progressively shortened, accelerated steps, rigidity, and a “pill-rolling” tremor. The first gene to be identified as a cause of Parkinson's Disease encodes a-synuclein, an abundant lipid-binding protein normally associated with synapses. Mutations in alpha-synuclein take the form of point mutations and amplification of the region of chromosome 4q21 that contains the gene. What is the mode of inheritance of these genes?

A 16-year-old boy presents to the hospital with complaints of lower limb weakness, respiratory distress, and unilateral facial paralysis. On examination, deep tendon reflex is absent. The level of proteins in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is raised. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?

According to the McDonald criteria for the diagnosis of multiple sclerosis, if a patient has 2 episodes separated in time and space, with clinical evidence of at least 2 lesions on MRI, what further investigations are required for the diagnosis of MS?

answers.option: No further requirement as clinical evidence alone suffices
Wait for another episode as further imaging needed
Wait for another lesion with additional attacks
Wait 1 year to assess disease progression
Wait for seeing a rise in intracranial pressure to perform lumbar puncture

question: A 50-year-old man suddenly developed a generalized tonic-clonic seizure during a social gathering. What is most important regarding first aid?

answers.option: Patient should be turned to his right side
To avoid tongue fall or bite insert a spoon in the patient's mouth
His clothes should be loosened and glasses removed
Stay calm and observe the duration of the attack
No oral treatment should be given until complete consciousness is regained

question: A seizing patient should be immediately taken to the hospital in what situation?

answers.option: Family history is positive for seizure disorder
Seizure starts when they are asleep

question: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room after a sudden loss of consciousness with generalized stiffness in the body and jerking limbs. He is otherwise well but according to his parents, he is clumsy and drops objects in the morning 2-3 times per week, such as a toothbrush, teaspoon, breakfast plates, and cutlery. This has been going on for the last year. His paternal uncle is reported to have had epilepsy. What is the next best management plan?

answers.option: EEG and MRI brain should be ordered
Cardiac arrhythmias should be ruled out first
Suspect metabolic derangement and send blood for biochemical profile immediately
Observe; usually treatment is not indicated in a single seizure

question: A 70-year-old man is brought to the outpatient department with complaints of repeating phrases and questions, performing prayers at inappropriate times, and often incorrect use of vocabulary. His condition has been deteriorating for the last 2 years. What best describes his condition?

answers.option: Currently available treatment only delays progression
Cause may be hepatic or renal failure
Inter-current illness, although common are not usually fatal
Genetics are more commonly involved in this etiology
This is part of normal aging

question: A 43-year-old man, with history of chronic alcoholism, often in his drunk state would physically and verbally abuse family members. He becomes amnestic of his aggressive behavior but felt ashamed the next morning when informed of his misconduct. These events occurred repeatedly every few weeks. Why cannot these events be called dementia?

answers.option: Patient is normal between the events
Gender does not favor the diagnosis of dementia
Patient is under the influence of alcohol at the time of events

question: A 72-year-old man is brought to the neurology clinic by his son with the complaints of forgetting his way back home from the mosque multiple times in the past few months. What is a useful clinical scale to confirm a suspected cause of the mental decline?

A 32-year-old lady presents to the emergency room with complaints of seizures for 3 hours, in the last two days she has had a high-grade fever with abnormal behavior and incoherent talk. On examination, there are no signs of meningeal irritation. Her blood glucose is 90 mg/dl. CT brain shows abnormal signals in both temporal lobes. Which of the following options most likely represents a cerebrospinal fluid detailed report for this patient?

answers.option: Protein 600 mg/dl, glucose 36 mg/dl, white blood cells 356/mm3, neutrophils 80%
Protein 90 mg/dl, glucose 73 mg/dl, white blood cells 38/mm3, lymphocytes 80%
Protein 39 mg/dl, glucose 79 mg/dl, white blood cells 2/mm3, lymphocytes 100%
Protein 800 mg/dl, glucose 24 mg/dl, white blood cells 498/mm3, lymphocytes 90%
Protein 246 mg/dl, glucose 70 mg/dl, white blood cells 3/mm3, lymphocytes 100%

question: Which of the following primary headaches is least commonly seen in neurology clinics?
What is the single most diagnostic bedside examination to rule out secondary malignant headache?
What should be the initial investigation for stroke?
What is the appearance of a cerebral hemorrhage in comparison to normal cerebral parenchyma in acute phase?
What is the investigation for chronic ataxia?
A 10-year-old boy requires drug treatment for absence seizures. He has a past history of multiple generalized tonic-clonic seizures as well. Which of the following drugs is best suited in this case?

A 22-year-old male swimmer presents in the emergency department with high-grade fever, headache, and neck stiffness. A provisional diagnosis of meningitis is made. What is the likely organism responsible for this presentation?

A 33-year-old male presents to the neurology clinic with complaints of recurrent headaches for 1 year. The headaches are constant in character and produce a tight band-like pain. The headache episode last for a few hours and relieves with pain killers. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 19-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with a complaint of muscle weakness for 8 months. After relevant examinations, the doctor ordered an evaluation of serum creatine kinase levels. The results show elevated levels of creatine kinase. What should be the next best step in the management of this patient?

A 44-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of mild fever for the past 3 months. The fever is associated with headaches, neck rigidity, malaise, and night sweats. His past medical history is significant for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection. On physical examination, vital signs include a temperature of 38 °C (100.4°F), a pulse of 85 beats/minute, a respiratory rate is 23 breaths/minute, and blood pressure of 130/85 mmHg. Serum electrolytes include glucose of 88 mg/dl. A lumbar puncture yields cloudy cerebrospinal fluid with a glucose of 32 mg/dl, protein of 146 mg/dl, and cell count of 3800 WBCs with predominant mononuclear cells, and a positive acid-fast bacillus (AFB) stain. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 41-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with worsening weakness in his right lower limb for the past three months. He also experiences extreme fatigue and pain in his limb. He has a medical history of a diagnosis of poliomyelitis at the age of 5 years which involved flaccid paralysis of the right lower limb that improved over a period of time. What is the likely diagnosis of this patient?
A patient has been diagnosed with a motor neuron-related problem. Which of the following findings will lead to a revision of the diagnosis?
A 23-year-old patient presents with loss of proprioception and two-point discrimination on the right side of the body. Which structure is most likely severed in this case?

A 35-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with difficulty in using his right hand with pain for 4 months. He also experiences paresthesias and numbness in the hand. On examination, the pain is reproduced on tapping the volar aspect of the wrist reflex hammer. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 16-year-old boy presents to the emergency department after sustaining a bullet injury on his back. After initial resuscitation, a complete head-to-toe examination is performed. On examination, the patient has loss of pain and temperature sensation on the right side of his body. Which structure is damaged in this case?

A 60-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with generalized weakness, pain in his limbs, and weight loss for 3 months. On examination, deep tendon reflexes are diminished. He has a 20-pack-year history of smoking. What is the likely diagnosis based on clinical suspicion?

A 30-year-old female presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of recurrent headaches and visual disturbances for 1 month. She is currently taking retinoid derivatives for the treatment of acne. Her body mass index (BMI) is 32 kg/m². On examination, fundoscopy reveals papilledema. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with weakness in his upper and lower limbs after falling from a height. The weakness is more in the upper limbs than the lower limbs. Which type of spinal cord injury is most likely responsible for this presentation?
What is the appropriate description for relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis?

answers.option: Frequent acute attacks and no recovery

question: Which of the following is appropriate regarding motor neuron disease?

answers.option: Disease is curative in early stage
Riluzole has small effect in increasing life expectancy up to 2 months

question: A 50-year-old male presents to the clinic with proptosis and a black necrotic mass present in the nasal cavity. What is the likely diagnosis?
Which of the following common causes of coma does not involve focal neurologic deficits?
A student is performing a neurological examination of a patient with positive lower motor neuron lesion findings. Which of the following finding will be seen in the patient?

A 45-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after experiencing a sudden "thunderclap" headache. The doctor ordered an urgent computed tomography scan and the results are inconclusive. What should be the next best investigation?
A patient is asked to protrude the tongue during a cranial nerve examination. It is observed that the tongue is deviated towards the right side. What is the cause of this finding?

A 35-year-old clerk who lives in a slum area of Sindh, presented in the emergency department with low-grade fever, headache, and irritability for 2 months and one episode of uprolling of eyes, jerking of limbs, and incontinence of urine one day back. He had a history of chronic productive cough for six months. On examination, his Glasgow coma scale (GCS) score was 10/15 and he had bilateral papilledema. Which best possible treatment regimen would be appropriate to start?

answers.option: Anti-tuberculosis therapy, steroids, and anti-seizure drugs

question: A 70-year-old male patient presented to the neurology outpatient department with complaints of slowness of walking and abnormal movements of hands for two years. On examination, the attending physician noted bradykinesia, postural instability, and resting tremors in both hands. The tremors were more pronounced in the left hand. What is the typical frequency of tremors in this case?

A 35-year-old female was referred to a tertiary care hospital with an hour history of sudden onset right-sided hemiplegia and aphasia. Her national institutes of health stroke scale (NIHSS) score was 20. The on-call neurologist was on board for consideration of an intravenous tissue plasminogen activator. He asked his junior to generate radiology requests immediately from the emergency department. Which specific imaging modality would be considered in this case?

answers.option: Computed tomography (CT) scan brain with contrast
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) brain and magnetic resonance angiogram (MRA)
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) brain and magnetic resonance venography (MRV)

question: A 30-year-old male presented to the outpatient department with complaints of difficulty in climbing the stairs and holding heavy objects in her hands for 4 months. It was associated with significant weight loss, dry cough, and muscle pain for 6 months. On examination, he was pale and febrile with generalized wasting. Proximal muscle powers were 3/5 with intact reflexes and downgoing plantar. Sensory examination was normal. What would be most likely seen on his muscle biopsy?

A 35-year-old male presented to the outpatient department with a complaint of sequential complete loss of vision in both eyes over one week. He had a history of both lower limb weakness 6 months back with minimal recovery despite taking treatment. On examination, he had no light perception in both eyes with bilateral pale disc. There was spastic quadriparesis with sensory level at the xiphisternum. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 78-year-old otherwise healthy male is brought to the outpatient department with complaints of increasing forgetfulness, subtle behavioral changes, and difficulty in managing home finances for 6 months. On examination, he is vitally stable and his mini-mental state examination (MMSE) score is 22/30. All other neurological examinations are normal. Which of the following are the initial and most common presenting symptoms of the suspected illness?

A 56-year-old female presented to the neurology outpatient department with complaints of multiple neurological symptoms that suddenly appeared two days ago. Her magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) brain showed an infarct in the left lateral medulla. Which of the following would most likely be present in this patient?

A 52-year-old diabetic man presents to the emergency room with complaints of right-sided weakness and inability to speak for one hour. Acute stroke treatment is planned for him. What is the immediate target to save this patient?

A 27-year-old female presents to the emergency room with complaints of high-grade fever for one day and seizures for two hours. On examination, she has recurrent seizures, a fever of 103 degrees Fahrenheit, and a rigid neck. There is no focal weakness and both plantars are mute. Which of the following investigations has the highest diagnostic yield in this patient?

A 65-year-old gentleman presents to the outpatient department with complaints of twitching and wasting of his leg muscles for the last 2 years. He has also been experiencing progressive weakness in both lower limbs. He often chokes while drinking water and suddenly starts laughing without any reason. On examination, he has wasting and fasciculations in all four limbs with hyperreflexia and extensor plantar responses. What area of his nervous system is most likely affected?

An 11-year-old male student is sent home from school because he daydreams in class and does not pay attention. During the clinical consultation, he becomes unresponsive for about 10-15 seconds. He stares blankly off into space and then suddenly resumes talking. He has no recollection that anything abnormal has happened. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old female presents to the emergency room. She is a known case of epilepsy and has been on no treatment for the last 2 weeks. She has generalized tonic-clonic seizures which are continuous for the last 30 minutes. On arrival in the emergency room, her oxygen saturation is 70% on room air. Seizures stop spontaneously but the patient does not regain consciousness. On examination, she is not opening her eyes even to painful stimuli. She is localizing a painful stimulus with both hands. She is making grunting noises at intervals. What is the Glasgow coma scale (GCS) score of this patient?

A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. On examination, there is a clear sensory level at the T6 dermatome on the left side of the body. Below this level, there is a loss of pain and temperature sensation on the left side and a loss of vibration and proprioception on the right side. Motor function is preserved on the right side but is impaired on the left side. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 20-year-old female presented with complaints of bilateral ptosis and fatigability for the last 2 years. After a clinical examination and confirmatory test, myasthenia gravis was diagnosed. Which of the following drugs would be safe to use?

A patient with Parkinson's disease presented at the rehabilitation medicine outpatient department for management. Which of the following statements is correct regarding rehabilitation management of Parkinson's disease?

answers.option: Auditory and visual queuing increase the risk of fall
Increased weighted utensils and adaptive equipment will improve the activities of daily living (ADLs)
The psychologist will give therapy to improve the activity of daily living (ADLs)
Exercise is harmful and increase the progress of disease
There are no rehabilitation management options available for Parkinson's disease

question: A 65-year-old male with a stroke presented to the rehabilitation outpatient department having left-sided hemiplegic and spastic gait. Which of the following orthosis is most commonly used to improve the gait of patients with stroke having spastic gait?

A 44-year-old male presented to the outpatient department with complaints of ascending weakness in all four limbs for 5 days. He was operated on for lumbar disc herniation 3 weeks back and became ambulatory within a week. On examination, he had grade 2/5 power in all four limbs with diminished reflexes and downgoing plantar. Which of the following investigation findings is most likely to be present in this patient?

A 6-year-old boy was brought to the outpatient department with complaints of frequent falls while running, and difficulty in rising from the ground. He had a positive family history of similar complaints. On examination, he was a young boy with an average build. Gait was lordotic. There was a scar mark over his right Achilles tendon. Powers were 4/5 in thigh muscles. Reflexes and sensations were normal. Which of the following is the most likely inheritance pattern of this disease?

An 18-year-old male presented with a history of frequent falls for the last two years. He had difficulty walking and due to imbalance became wheelchair-bound. He also had difficulty in carrying out daily household work describing a lack of precision. His family also noticed that his speech appeared to be drunken. He had no disturbance in memory and intellectual ability. His sister also had a similar illness. On examination, he had dysarthric speech, truncal ataxia, and bilateral upgoing planters with absent ankle reflex. Regarding the above clinical scenario, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A 50-year-old male presented with complaints of left-sided facial pain involving half-face only. The pain was aggravated with eating, chewing, and shaving. The pain was sharp, stabbing, sudden, and current-like. No associated complaints of hearing loss and tinnitus were reported. Neurological examination was unremarkable. What would be the most likely diagnosis?

A spinal cord injury patient having C6 American Spinal Injury Association (ASIA) impairment scale grade A, admitted to the ward suddenly complained of severe headache, flushing, dizziness, and disoriented. Her blood pressure was 160/100 mm Hg and her Foley catheter was clogged. What can be the most common diagnosis?

A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room by his parents. He has been complaining of headache, fever, and stiff neck for the past 2 days. He is also vomiting and has had no appetite. On physical examination, he is found to be febrile (102°F) and Kerning's sign is present. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. His computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain is normal. What investigation will be appropriate to perform to reach a diagnosis?

answers.option: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) brain with contrast

question: A 45-year-old man, a known case of diabetes with good glycemic control, was referred to the emergency room with a diagnosis of ischemic stroke. He developed weakness in his left upper and lower limbs 2 hours ago. His blood pressure was 130/80 mmHg and his blood sugar was normal. His computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain showed a right frontal infarct. He had no significant history. All laboratory investigations were normal. What would be the best treatment for this patient?
A young man is brought to the emergency room with a severe sudden headache within 2 hours after the onset. Which finding should be looked for in plain computed tomography (CT) brain?

answers.option: Mixed high and low density in subcortical white matter
High density in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) spaces

question: A 42-year-old female, a known case of multiple sclerosis for 5 years, presented with a complaint of fatigue. She has been taking teriflunomide for 3 years which resulted in complete remission. She was diagnosed with depression and prescribed fluoxetine 2 years back which managed her depression. What would be an appropriate treatment option for her fatigue?
Which of the following exhibits neuropathy with autonomic features?
A patient comes to the clinic with a history of meningitis. He now complains of headaches and papilledema. What would be seen on a computed tomography (CT) scan?

A 7-year-old boy is brought to the ER with complaints of symmetric weakness in lower limbs, progressing to involve the trunk in 3 days. On examination, the plantar reflexes are down-going, and tone and reflexes are decreased in both lower limbs. What is the most appropriate investigation that you will suggest?

An 8-year-old child is brought to the ER with complaints of progressive weakness in lower limbs for 5 days and now involving the trunk with respiratory difficulty. On examination of lower limbs, reflexes are absent, power is reduced to 2/5 in both the lower limbs. CSF analysis shows increased protein. What is the most appropriate management in this child?

A 3-year-old child with no medical history was brought into the emergency department with a 1-day history of seizures and altered mental status. A head CT was obtained that reported an intraparenchymal hemorrhage. The patient was then stabilized and taken for a diagnostic angiogram, which was suggestive of an arteriovenous malformation (AVM). What will be your most appropriate next step for management?

answers.option: Give immediate bolus for surgical intervention

question: A 34-year-old male presents with vomiting preceded by an occipital headache of acute onset. On examination, he is conscious, alert, has photophobia, and positive neck stiffness. CT head is reported as normal. What is the most appropriate investigation to confirm the diagnosis?

A 44-year-old woman presents with pain in her right hand and forearm, which has been worsening over the past few weeks. There is no history of trauma. The pain is concentrated around the thumb and index finger and is often worse at night. Shaking her hand seems to provide some relief. On examination, there is weakness of the abductor pollicis brevis and reduced sensation to fine touch at the index finger. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 6-year-old child presented to OPD with history of diarrhea for about 3 days and weakness on right side of body since morning. On examination HR 120b/min, RR 28/min, O2 96%, BP 90/64 mmHg. He is awake and follows commands. On examination left leg power 5/5, right arm power 3/5, right leg power 2/5, reflexes are brisk on right side. What will be the investigation of choice for his management?

A 4-year-old boy presented with weakness of left upper limb upon awakening. Past history was insignificant. On examination GCS was 15/15, cranial nerve intact, sensory system intact. Bulk normal in all 4 limbs. Tone and reflexes were normal in all the limbs except left upper limb where these were reduced. The most likely possibility for this presentation is:

A 34-year-old lady, with type 1 diabetes, presents to OPD with episodic headaches for the last 3 years, which are unilateral, throbbing in nature, associated with nausea and vomiting, phono-photophobia, occurring twice a week for last one month. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is a brainstem reflex that must be checked in a comatose patient?
Which of the following develop in the brain of Alzheimer’s patients and may cause the disease?

A 25-year-old male was seen in the emergency room with a left-sided throbbing headache, nausea, left-sided ptosis, and lacrimation. He has been having these attacks daily for the last 3 days. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 20-year-old female presents to the ER with sudden severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. On examination, she has a GCS of 15/15, severe neck rigidity, ptosis on the right side, and dilated right pupil. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old woman presents with three episodes of visual loss. She has recently developed an ataxic gait and often drops objects from her grip. On examination, her speech is slurred, and there is evidence of dysdiadochokinesia. A fundoscopy was performed and showed a pale optic disc. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old man sustained a serious head injury in a road traffic collision. Two weeks later, he was still unarousable, failing to respond to stimuli, with no sleep-wake cycles or any voluntary actions. What is the most accurate description of this disorder?

A 22-year-old was hit by a car and had a head impact 4 hours ago. Following the incident, he developed vomiting and decreased consciousness. In the ER, he had one episode of tonic-clonic seizure. Examination showed a right eye bruise and a GCS of 10/15. Which is the most important diagnostic investigation?
What is the primary goal of treatment for muscular dystrophy?

answers.option: To manage symptoms and improve quality of life
To reduce the progression of disease

question: Which diagnostic tool is considered the gold standard for diagnosing myelopathy?
Which of the following is the most common site for hemorrhagic stroke:
What is the duration of a transient ischemic attack (TIA)?
Parkinsonism includes a combination of the following:
What is the investigation of choice for Parkinson's Disease:
Which of the following is the most common symptom of Multiple Sclerosis?

A patient came to the ER with a complaint of severe sudden onset headache associated with vomiting, according to him he has never had such kind of headache in the past. Which radiological examination would you advise as it is faster, easy to interpret, and has no contraindication for any foreign body?
MRI Brain is the best radiological modality for selected pathologies, which of the following best represents the set of diseases in which MRI scan is the gold standard?

answers.option: Brain tumor, metastasis, Dural venous sinus thrombosis

question: After recovering from a severe head injury, a patient is living with permanent disability and unable to join his previous social activities but can live an independent life. What is his Glasgow outcome score?
Which of the following disease processes usually doesn't need surgical intervention after trauma primarily until and unless intracranial pressure is not managed by conservative treatment?

A patient comes to the ER after a head injury. His GCS is 10/15. You suspect raised intracranial pressure as he is hypertensive, tachypneic, and his heart rate is reduced. What is this clinical presentation known as?
In principle, the pressure is distributed evenly throughout the cranial cavity, and the sum of all intracranial volumes is always constant because of which of the following reasons:

answers.option: The cavity is elastic and close
The cavity is inelastic and closed
The cavity is elastic and open
The cavity is inelastic and open

question: The smallest physiological motion unit of the spine to exhibit biomechanical characteristics similar to those of the entire spine is called?
In the final stages of disc degeneration, what is the likely radiological finding?

answers.option: Disc has central horizontal line of low-signal intensity
Homogenous low signal with no distinction between nucleus and annulus
Disc has high intensity in the central part of the disc and low intensity in the peripheral part of the disc
Disc has low signal intensity centrally and blurring of distinction between nucleus and annulus
Disc has uniformly high signal on T2

question: 71 years old male came to neurology OPD, with presenting symptoms of alterations in mental status, fever & headache. MRI shows inflammation in the temporal lobe. Which of the following organisms may show inflammatory infiltrates & Cowdry Type A intranuclear viral inclusion bodies, and found in neurons and glia?

An infant, who presents complaints of headache, photophobia, irritability, bulging fontanelle, fever & neck stiffness. The introduction of vaccination against which of the following has markedly reduced the incidence of acute pyogenic meningitis in the developed world, particularly among infants, who used to be at high risk?

65 years old male came to neurology OPD, he has complaints of deficits in memory, visuospatial orientation, judgment, personality, and language. Which of the following are the major microscopic abnormalities of Alzheimer’s disease?

answers.option: Cowdry Type A Intranuclear Inclusion Bodies

question: A 65-year-old male with a stroke presented to Rehabilitation OPD having left-side hemiplegia and spastic gait. Which of the following orthosis is most commonly used to improve gait of patients with stroke having spastic gait?
A person with Parkinson’s Disease presented at Rehabilitation Medicine OPD for management. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the rehabilitation management of Parkinson's disease?

answers.option: Exercise is harmful and increase the progress of disease
Psychologist will give therapy to improve Activity of daily living ADLs
Increased weighted utensils and adaptive equipment will improve ADLs.
There are no rehabilitation management options available for Parkinson’s disease.
Auditory and visual queuing increase risk of fall

question: An 18-month-old unvaccinated child presented with the inability to stand and bear weight on the left foot. On examination, the child was conscious, febrile, and unable to stand or walk with decreased tone, power, and reflexes in the left lower limb. Plantars were going down. A junior resident on duty ordered an MRI of the brain with contrast. Keeping the most likely diagnosis in mind, which investigation needs to be done on priority?

A 7-year-old vaccinated girl presented with progressive asymmetrical weakness of lower limbs over a short period. Both limbs were flaccid, with no cranial nerve involvement. Tone and power in the lower limbs were decreased to 2/5, and reflexes were diminished. Sensory examination was normal, as were the upper limbs. The child was conscious and cooperative. What do these clinical findings most likely describe?

A 64-year-old male presented with sudden-onset high fever, severe headache, neck stiffness, and altered mental status. On examination, he had positive Brudzinski's sign and photophobia. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis showed elevated white blood cell count with predominantly neutrophils, low glucose, and elevated protein. What should be the empirical treatment?

A 45-year-old male with a history of chronic sinusitis presented with a severe headache, fever, and right-sided weakness. He also had papilledema on examination. CT scan of the brain revealed a ring-enhancing lesion in the left frontal lobe. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

answers.option: Perform lumbar puncture with cerebrospinal fluid analysis
Start empirical antibiotics with surgical consultation

question: Which of the intracerebellar nuclei is not present in the white matter of the cerebellar hemisphere?
Which of the following areas do cortical branches of the anterior cerebral artery supply?
Which of the following is the only cranial nerve arising from the posterior surface of the brain?
A brain-dead patient will have a GCS (Glasgow Coma Scale) of?

A 55-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of highly variable drooping of both upper eyelids and transient double vision, especially in the evening. On examination, she has striking bilateral fatigable ptosis, double vision on sustained lateral gaze, with easily visible, and fatigable weakness of the medial recti, mild weakness of the neck flexion, and fatigable weakness of shoulder abduction and hip flexion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is the most common site involved in herpetic encephalitis?

A 25-year-old woman presented with a history of intermittent dysphagia. She was unable to hang out more than four items of washed clothing to dry without resting and had experienced breathlessness over the past 6 months. On examination, she had neck flexor weakness and weak proximal arm muscles. Her sensory examination and tendon reflexes were normal. His lab investigations reveal: Serum-corrected calcium: Normal, Serum phosphate: Normal, Serum creatine kinase: Mildly elevated, Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone and FT4: Normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Haloperidol is not a suitable treatment option for which of the following conditions?
Which SSRI is the least likely to inhibit CYP2D6 and CYP3A4 resulting in fewer drug interactions?

A 32-year-old woman presents for a right distal radius fracture. She requests regional anesthesia to help with her pain postoperatively. She reports that as a child, she had an allergic reaction to Novocain (procaine) at the dentist’s office. Which local anesthetic is appropriate for use in this patient?

A patient with a spinal cord injury at C6 is admitted to the ward and suddenly complains of severe headache, flushing, dizziness, and disorientation. Her Foley catheter was clogged. Her BP was 160/100 mmHg. What is your diagnosis?

A 21-year-old male is brought to the OPD by his father with complaints of social isolation, speaking to himself, and claiming that there are cameras in his room through which aliens spy on him, for the past 7 months. At times, he starts trembling and crying and says, "They are going to kill me," whereas sometimes he starts laughing out loud. He refuses to eat anything cooked at home, claiming it is poisoned. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old woman with diabetes, hypertension, and dyslipidemia presented with muscle pain and weakness in her proximal arms and legs for three weeks. She has been taking treatment for her comorbid conditions for the past two to three months. Examination showed 4/5 power in proximal muscles. Laboratory investigations revealed elevated creatine kinase levels. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
Which part of the twelfth cranial nerve receives fibers only from the contralateral cerebral cortex?

answers.option: The part supplying the styloglossus muscle
The part supplying the genioglossus muscle
The part supplying the intrinsic muscles of the tongue
The part supplying the hyoglossus muscle
The part supplying the palatoglossus muscle

question: In which of the following conditions general anesthesia cannot be given?

answers.option: Any patient can be given general anesthesia

question: A 30-year-old software engineer presents with complaints of intense worrying about trivial issues that interfere with his performance for 1 month. He has recently started a new job at a fast-paced tech company. He has felt increasingly stressed due to long work hours and high-performance expectations. He finds himself thinking about work even during his time off, which occasionally makes it difficult to fall asleep. He also has occasional heart palpitations, sweating, and a sense of dread that he struggles to control. Which of the following best distinguishes this patient’s experience as an anxiety disorder rather than a normal state of stress?

answers.option: Increased stress due to high expectations at a new job
Persistent, intense worry that disrupts his functioning
Preoccupation with work tasks outside of work hours

question: A 61 years old male came to the emergency, with complaints of headache, photophobia, irritability, clouding of consciousness, and neck stiffness. A spinal tap yields cloudy or frankly purulent CSF, with as many as 90,000 neutrophils per cubic millimeter, an increased protein concentration, and markedly reduced glucose content. Bacteria may be seen on a smear or may be cultured. Which of the following microorganisms cause Acute Pyogenic (Bacterial) Meningitis in older adults?

A college student is brought to the emergency department by friends. The physician is informed that the student had taken a drug and then "went crazy." The patient is agitated and delirious. Several persons are required to hold him down. His skin is warm and sweaty, and his pupils are dilated. Bowel sounds are normal. Signs and symptoms include tachycardia, marked hypertension, hyperthermia, increased muscle tone, and both horizontal and vertical nystagmus. The most likely cause of these symptoms is intoxication from?

A 25-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of highly variable drooping of both upper eyelids, transient double vision, especially in the evening, and “fatigue.” On examination, she has striking bilateral fatigable ptosis, double vision on sustained lateral gaze with easily visible fatigable weakness of the medial recti, mild weakness of neck flexion, and fatigable weakness of shoulder abduction and hip flexion. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 68-year-old male has a progressive weakness for the last 2 years. He says that weakness started in his left upper limb, then involved his right lower limb, followed by his left lower limb and then his right upper limb. He had no vision problems or bowel and bladder dysfunction. On examination, he has tongue fasciculations, weakness of all four limbs, fasciculations in limb muscles, brisk reflexes, and positive babinski sign. He does not have any sensory deficits. His NCS/EMG shows widespread denervation patterns. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 5-year-old boy was brought to the clinic with complaints of delayed motor milestones, difficulty in climbing stairs, and frequent falls. On examination, the child was walking with a protuberant abdomen and using his hands to push himself up from the floor. Which of the following findings are most likely to be present on examination?

answers.option: Spasticity and clonus in lower limbs
Distal muscle atrophy with normal reflexes

question: A 38-year-old man presented with complaints of progressive muscle weakness and difficulty lifting objects for 6 months. It was associated with significant weight loss, dry cough, and muscle pain. On examination, he had 3/5 power in proximal muscles with intact reflexes and normal sensation. Laboratory tests revealed an elevation in creatine kinase levels. Electromyography showed signs of irritable myopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old woman presented with a history of multiple episodes of unconsciousness for the last few months. Each episode lasted for 2-3 minutes and she had no recall of events. The investigation didn't reveal any neurological deficit. Which of the following investigations would be the most appropriate?
There are four principal routes by which microbes enter the nervous system. Which of the following virus may be transported along the nervous system?
